dialogues.speaker: THE EYE 2
dialogues.text: It's magnified and deeply revealed.  Flecks of green and yellow in a field of milky blue.  Icy filaments surround the undulating center. The eye is brown in a tiny screen.  On the metallic surface below, the words VOIGHT-KAMPFF are finely etched.  There's a touch-light panel across the top and on the side of the screen, a dial that registers fluctuations of the iris. The instrument is no bigger than a music box and sits on a table between two men.  The man talking is big, looks like an over-stuffed kid.  "LEON" it says on his breast pocket.  He's dressed in a warehouseman's uniform and his pudgy hands are folded expectantly in his lap.  Despite the obvious heat, he looks very cool. The man facing him is lean, hollow cheeked and dressed in gray.  Detached and efficient, he looks like a cop or an accountant.  His name is HOLDEN and he's all business, except for the sweat on his face. The room is large and humid.  Rows of salvaged junk are stacked neatly against the walls.  Two large fans whir above their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay if I talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden doesn't answer.  He's centering Leon's eye on the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kinda get nervous when I take tests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries not to move but finally his lips can't help a sheepish smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already had I.Q. test this year -- but I don't think I never had a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in) Reaction time is a factor in this, so please pay attention.  Answer quickly as you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon compresses his lips and nods his big head eagerly. Holden's voice is cold, geared to intimidate and evoke response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in a desert, walking along in the sand when all of a sudden you look down and see a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a timid interruption, hardly audible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What desert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't make any difference what desert -- it's completely hypothetical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how come I'd be there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're fed up, maybe you want to be by yourself -- who knows.  So you look down and see a tortoise.  It's crawling towards you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tortoise.  What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what a turtle is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never seen a turtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Holden's patience is wearing thin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I understand what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You reach down and flip the tortoise over on its back, Leon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeping an eye on his subject, Holden notes the dials in the Voight-Kampff.  One of the needles quivers slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make these questions, Mr. Holden, or they write 'em down for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disregarding the question, Holden continues, picking up the pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tortoise lays on its back, its belly baking in the hot sun, beating its legs trying to turn itself over.  But it can't.  Not without your help.  But you're not helping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon's upper lip is quivering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha mean, I'm not helping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean you're not helping! Why is that, Leon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon looks shocked, surprised.  But the needles in the computer barely move.  Holden goes for the inside of his coat.  But big Leon is faster.  His LASER BURNS a hole the size of a nickel through Holden's stomach. Unlike a bullet, a laser causes no impact.  It goes through Holden's spine and comes out his back, clean as a whistle.  Like a rag doll he falls back off the bench from the waist up.  By the time he hits the floor, big slow Leon is already walking away.  But he stops, turns and with a little smile of satisfaction, FIRES at the machine on the table. There's a flash and a puff of smoke.  The Voight-Kampff is hit dead center, crippled but not destroyed; as Leon walks out of the room, one of its lights begins to blink, faint but steady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horizon marked by a thin copper line that maybe the end, of the beginning of a day. The train that follows, cuts through the night at 400 miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No clickitty-clack of track-bound noise, it's a long, insulated Pullman of contoured seats and low-keyed lighting, coloured to soothe,and empty, except for the passenger half way down. His eyes closed, head rested against the glass.  Ten years ago, DECKARD might have been an athlete, a track man or a welter-weight.  The body looks it, but the face has seen some time -- not all of it good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard comes down the aisle, slips a coin into the mechanism, receives a beer and returns to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired of the program, he takes off the headset and drops it next to three empty beer bottles and a sandwich wrapper, adjusts his position and winds up staring at his reflection in the window.  Runs a hand over his face, it could use a shave.  He leans closer and peers through the glass. Out there in the black a sign flashes past:  SAN ANGELES, THREE MINUTES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train slides in, smooth as an eel, and stops with- out a sound.  Carrying a bag and umbrella, Deckard disembarks ahead of the other passengers and into the sweltering night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard has got his coat swung over his shoulder, his shirt already damp, as he walks down the long, hollow passage under orbs of yellow light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard unlocks his car and gets in.  Turns the ig- nition and hits a sensor.  The dash console glows and Deckard sits back waiting for the air unit to cool things off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was 97 degrees in the city and no hope of improvement.  Not bad if you're a lizard.  But two hours earlier I was drinking Acquavit with an Eskimo lady in North East Alaska.  That's a tough change to make.  It was so good, I didn't want to leave, so I left a day early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little detached, Deckard taps another sensor on the panel, lights up a cigarette and watches as his mes- sages flash across the viewer stating date, time and caller.  The last one is repeated five times.  Deckard sighs, switches off the viewer and gets on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Contact.  This is Blade Runner One calling Com-fast 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND OF A CHIME precedes the mechanical female voice that answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blade Runner One, stand by please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.  Followed by a husky male voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yah, Gaff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where I been.  I been on vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time you go on vacation, do me a favor, let us know where it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden got hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause.  That was bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Severed spine.  You'd better get in here.  Bryant's waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ENGINE REVS, the wipers rake two weeks of dust off the windshield and Deckard jams out of the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enormous grey vault of a building.  A businesslike Deckard strides down a long corridor with his brief- case and police ID pinned to his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-X-4-P-D referred to as a Nexus-6, The Tyrell Corporation's new pride and joy.  Holden was administering the Voight-Kampff test when one nailed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door in front of Deckard slides open and he walks through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nexus-6 must be fast because Holden was as quick as they come. The report said there were six of them.  Three males and three female. Led by a combat model called Roy Batty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The INSPECTOR is in his fifties.  The deep creases in his face, the broken capillaries in his nose say brawler, spoiler, drinker, but the diplomas on the wall say something else.  Bryant's kneeled at his safe trying to open it.  Deckard it sitting on the edge of the desk reading the print-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They escaped from the colonies two weeks ago.  Killed twenty- three people and jumped a shuttle. An aerial patrol found the ship in the desert.  No crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryant gets the safe open and brings out a bottle of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryant's got a liver problem.  A couple years back he handed me a bottle and said have a drink for another man.  I been drinking for him ever since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard sets down the report and takes the shot Bryant just poured for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five.  Three nights ago one of them managed to break into the Tyrell Corporation.  Killed two guards and got as far as the Genetic Sector before he got fried going through an electro- field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was he after?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There wasn't much left of him, so we can't be sure.  But bio- chemical data and morphology records of the Nexus-6 were reported missing.  Going on the possibility they might try to infiltrate we send Holden in to run Voight-Kampff tests on the new employees.  Guess he found himself one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grim pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a machine on it yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're using Esper -- a 231 -- that picked up Holden's alarm.  Its guess is that all five are in the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do we start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryant's back at the safe locking up his bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tyrell Corporation has a demo model.  Check it out on the Voight-Kampff.  There's a chance the Nexus-6 is beyond out ability to detect.  If that's the case, everybody's up shit creek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was the cover on the one that got Holden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Industrial refuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garbage man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryant nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did personnel have an address on him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryant fishes a piece of paper out of his pocket, copies down a number and hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go take a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard stands and holds up his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a sick boy looking out of the window, Bryant watches Deckard down the whiskey.  Deckard puts down the glass and turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big incentive to emigrate was still free labor.  If the public found out that their door-prizes might kill them, they might not be so hot to go up there.  This was one of the worst one's we had and Bryant was worried.  He wanted to tell me to be discrete or something. But I didn't give him a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An electrical storm is brewing.  Deckard stands out- side the entrance to an old hotel holding an umbrella, as people scuttle into doorways to avoid the sudden downpour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heavy metal maze of cubicles and perilous iron balconies, peopled with rejects from the surface world; Mato Grosso Indians in white man's clothes and other lower echelon welfare recipients.  Drop city is crowded, cramped and darkly alive. Deckard steps out of an elevator and moves through the crowd.  A cloud of steam drifts up through  a grating as two old men, clad in towels descend a flight of stairs under a neon sign that says bath house. A musty subterranean wind ripples Deckard's clothes as he turns into an alcove.  He stops in front of a door that says, MANAGER and pushes the buzzer.  It's opened by an emphysema victim with an oxygen tank lashed to his hip.  Deckard flashes his ID and speaks some words which are inaudible due to the TUBA MUSIC down the hall. The man grabs a key from his wall, hands it over and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The companion ways below deck of a big ship are no more bewildering than the ups and downs and ins and outs of this establishment.  But Deckard finds the door he's looking for.  He pauses a moment, listens, then knocks.  He inserts the key and with a hand on his gun opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty room.  A cot and not much else.  He steps in and stands quiet as a hunter sensing the signs.  For a place surrounded by greasy hovels it is surprisingly clean.  Spartan in fact.  The towel by the spotless basin is perfectly folded. Deckard runs two fingers over a shelf.  No dust.  He looks in the waste basket.  Wadded up candy wrappers. The bed by the window is neatly made.  Deckard looks under it, then runs his hands along both sides of the mattress. The closet.  There's one suit in it.  He pats it down. Nothing. A show box on the floor.  He stoops, takes out what looks like a pen from his pocket and care- fully traces it over the box.  Assured of its harm- lessness, he lifts off the lid. It contains a little stack of photos bound with a rubber band.  Deckard removes them, goes to the lamp by the balcony window and turns it on. A touching collection of family snapshots.  The kind of anonymous stuff sold by the bunch in dusty junk shops. The family dog.  Junior on the pony squinting in the sun.  Uncle Ben clowning with the kids.  The faded polaroid of Christmas morning.  Simple pictures of simple folks celebrating the family bond.  A curious collection for the likes of Leon and Deckard studies them with interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblivious to the cloudburst, a blue-eyed albino stands in the doorway, peddling candy and artificial flowers looking like he'd never been touched by the light of day. Leon is standing behind him, staring up at his room, watching Deckard at the window.  He's still wearing his coveralls, but he looks different.  His face is more intent, smarter and angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For one seething moment it looks like Leon might mash something, but suddenly he swings away and disappears into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard pockets the pictures and moves away from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon's got a neck like a fire hydrant and legs to match, but he's a graceful runner.  Looks like he could do it for days.  And he could.  He's put a lot of alley behind him and he's not out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowing down he cuts into an opening and comes out onto a narrow street.  The Asian Quarter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A seamy as well as steamy little place.  Counter and small tables.  Old slant-eyed enders humped over their fuming bowls jabbering and slurping. The only voice coming out clear is from the big three- D TV on the back wall.  As the mellow-mouthed TV announcer delivers the message, a Latin-looking beauty in a well-fitted maids uniform does a twirl, flashes a beguiling smile and glides OUT OF FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Choose from a variety of seventy nine different personality types. Each and every one a loyal trouble- free companion given to you upon your arrival absolutely free...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Latin beauty is replaced by an impeccable Ray Bolger type gentleman's gentleman who clicks his heels, snaps to attention and struts off to make room for the next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To use as personal body servant to tireless field hand -- the custom tailored humanoid robot, designed especially for your needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chinese are paying no attention, but the man and the woman seated at the table by the window are. The woman is pretty, a touch of gray in her hair, kind and blue-eyed.  MARY looks like an American dream mom, right out of "Father Knows Best." The man also resembles a tradition: the gym instructor, short cropped hair with the body of a drill sergeant, but the eyes are grey and chilling.  ROY BATTY is a presence of force with a lazy, but acute sense of what goes on around him. Leon has just come through the door behind them.  Try- ing not to be the bull in a china shop, he approaches their table and kneels .  Batty doesn't bother to look at him, which amplifies the note of sarcasm in his quiet voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get your precious 'things'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody was already there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon looks sullen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one next to him.  Leon pulls it over and sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoy the view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the pot on the table, Mary pours tea and they sit so quiet and still in this noisy place that they seem almost invisible.  The view they're "enjoying" is through the window.  Outside the neon side in the win- dow directly across the street says:  HANNIBAL CHEW, MEMBERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chew is a spindly old man of precision, his veiled eyes are shrewd and Chinese, but the rest of him looks like a Charles Dickens invention. He's got a jewelers' glass stuck in his eye, lurched over a lamp, squinting at something in his hand.  After a moment his lips peal back into a sour, belligerent smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're right.  This little honey has a couple of defective cones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snaps off the lamp and swings round to face his client. SEBASTIAN'S face is almost young, but something has gone too far, too fast.  Premature old age has made his bones brittle and his co-ordination slow.  The house may be dark but there's a light on in it.  Se- bastian is a closet genius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a regular perfectionist, Sebastian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian's apologetic, especially around the acerbic Mr. Chew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gotta be right for my customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your customer, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chew snickers and beckons.  Sebastian follows his down a high narrow hall to a heavy insulated door.  There's a moth-eaten full length fur coat hanging by it.  Chew tugs it on and they go through.  The big door slams shut behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except for the work table with its sharp gleaming in- struments, the room is as barren and sterile as a morgue.  The glass-doored compartments in the walls look like crypts.  Some of them small as post office boxes.  From one of the Chew removes a vacuum, packed box.  Carefully separating the seal, he reaches into the purple jell and with a pair of tweezers extracts an eye. Through the jeweler's glass, which he has not bothered to remove, Chew holds the eye up to the light and studies it a moment.  His other hand searches through his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a pocket-charger, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick to accommodate, Sebastian removes a pencil-like device from a row of such things in his breast pocket and steps closer.  The back of the eye is touched with the pencil and the pupil moves.  Suddenly its staring back at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that good enough for your customer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anxious to leave, Sebastian nods.  Chew reseals the eye taking his time.  He can afford to, he's wearing his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is he paying you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In place of an answer, Sebastian clears his throat, stares at the bag like he didn't hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, when do you get paid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon as I finish the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When might that be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Day after tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!  Day after tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian nods.  Chew stares at the poor bastard, con- cerned in spite of himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rich hate to pay, Sebastian. A guy like Tyrell keeps you waiting. Pay the little guy last.  You should charge twice as much.  It'll make him feel better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian nods his head like that's exactly what he'll do.  Chew sees it's hopeless and hands him the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mr. Chew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chew pulls the door open for him and Sebastian goes through quick as a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian may lack co-ordination but he got what he came for and there's a hopeful spring to his walk as he heads for his truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an old panel job with ambulance siren and lights. The lettering on the side reads "J.R. SEBASTIAN - ANIMOID EXPRESS."  Sebastian gets in, starts up the engine and suddenly realizes he's not alone.  It's a jolt that causes him to yelp. PRIS is sprawled on the seat next to him, and wakes up with a yelp of her own.  They stare at one another for a startled instant, and she jumps out and starts walk- ing. But she's forgotten her little beat-up overnight case. Sebastian puts the truck in gear, drives next to her and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  You forgot your...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up the bag.  Hesitantly she reaches for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you were in my truck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was tired and didn't have any place to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him, hand on her case, looking lost. Sebastian isn't good at this, but he tries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can get back in if you want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't make up her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I won't hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets in.  Both of them are silent.  People are not Sebastian's medium -- usually he's too shy, but this girl is shyer still, plus they're about the same age -- it gives him courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine's J.F. Sebastian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So pleased with the way that went, he forgets for a while what comes next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!  Where do you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shrugs.  That leaves him a lot of responsibility. He throws her side-long glances, but she's not helping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do with a teenage beauty who looks like she's lost out of some "Welcome to Sunny Arizona" poster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are your folks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have some, but I have to find out where they are staying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans forward and rests her elbows on the dash. Her body would win prizes, from any angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, where should I take you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him,a shadow of enticement in her clear blue eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We scared each other pretty good didn't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sure did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She giggles and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hungry, J.F.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got stuff.  If you wanna go to my place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping you'd say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian's face is normally on the grey side, but it just turned red.  He turns on the ignition and they pull away from the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speeding along the freeway.  The terminal in the com- munications console lit.  Deckard's right hand just finished a punch-up.  The screen flashes back.

dialogues.speaker: REQUEST
dialogues.text: Deckard punches up.  Letters flash across the screen:

dialogues.speaker: ESPER
dialogues.text: Screen flashes back:

dialogues.speaker: CLEARANCE
dialogues.text: Deckard punches up.

dialogues.speaker: BLADE RUNNER ONE CODE ML-33
dialogues.text: Pause. Screen flashes: STAND BY. Deckard's voice has been heard over the preceding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Machines can be helpful sometimes, but they can also be a pain in the ass.  Ask for a trace on a forger and you might wind up at a steel- mill.  I don't mind a bum-steer once in a while -- it's their personalities that usually get me.  Somebody once said that man makes machines in his own image.  If that's true, whoever made Esper should have been shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Esper and I'm ready.  Go ahead please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esper's deep melodious voice is anxious to please, and oiled with a touch of self-pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You equipped for random questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five in question are third generation Nexus Sixes, constructed of skin-flesh culture, selected enogenic transfer conversion capable of self-perpetuating thought, para-physical abilities and developed for emigration program.  Are you with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I stop one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike a five, they can sustain massive traumas to several parts of the body without debilitating another.  Sever a leg and it will perform quicker on the remaining leg than the fastest man can run,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm coming to that.  Vulnerable zone is the base of the skull, the occipital bone.  A direct hit is a positive retirement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The communication is interrupted by a BELL which is immediately followed by a stern, MECHANICAL VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are in violation of traffic ordinance M-139 statutory freeway limit restricted by one-hundred and eighty kilometers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his rear view mirror Deckard sees two black-clad motorcycle cops coming up behind him like the hounds of hell.  They draw silently alongside.  Deckard presses his I.D. to the window. The cop tosses a salute to Deckard and he and his partner accelerate, vanish in the night.  And Deckard's car does too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A district of silence and ruin.  The street is strewn with refuse.  The building looks vacant.  A ten storey condo gone to shit.  The vandals have come and gone long ago. Sebastian's little white ambulance parked at the curb. MR. DEETCHUM, the old Watchman, sitting in the building entry in a straight backed chair, is reading a comic book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well stocked with items of survival, all labeled and stacked.  And shelved along the walls and hung from the ceiling is a menagerie of animoids.  Like so many broken toys awaiting resurrection from Sebastian's wise hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian is seated at a large work-table, bent over a stereo scope.  The tool in his right hand is a sensor probe and he's using it with the delicacy of an en- graver. The object of his concentration is a maze-like chip configuration no bigger than a thumbnail, but magnified under the scope, it looks like an aerial view of a large city.  The needle-like sensor probe moves care- fully over the contours of the configuration, testing the bonds. Suddenly a blue flash erupts from one of the junctures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pris is light on her feet.  She's standing behind him with a half-eaten sandwich in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You scared me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's happy to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's changed her dress and made up her face.  Looks a little older and sexier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look... better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches her as she prowls around the room, looking at this and that, eating her sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you live in this building all by yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I live here pretty much alone right now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to make light of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No housing shortage around here... plenty of room for everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sprawls on the couch studying him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't meet her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not an easy subject.  His voice is barely audible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Methuselah Syndrome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My glands.  They grow old too fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why you're still here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I couldn't pass the test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a silence.  He steals a glance at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you just the way you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the desk he bats his knees together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, you get hold of your friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact I did.  They've got some work to do tonight, but they're gonna come tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The implications catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can sleep on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little gray mouse on the shelf above his head bobs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let the bed bugs bite!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking their cue from the mouse, some of the more talented animoids toot, flap and wheel about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark except for the glow of the terminal.  A tired Deckard sits in front of it.  Esper sounds like he's been talking for hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nexus designated Leon:  incept date April 10th, 2015 -- to be used in military experiments to determine how hyper metabolism functions in deep space. Nexus designated Batty incept data April 10th, 2015, combat model, level of self-sufficiency, optimum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's something you might find interesting.  They have been built to emulate the human in every way except in its emotional spectrum. However, after a period of time it is only logical that such a 'mechanism' would create its own emotional responses, hate, love, fear, anger, envy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know all that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about a summary then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we're through for the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard starts to reach for the panel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deckard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have something against science?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if it works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what in your estimation works?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard picks up the umbrella and with it stabs the terminal off button before Esper can respond and the machine goes dead.  He sits there for a moment then flips on the lamp.  Leon's snap-shots are spread out before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police marked spinner makes a sharp bank, drops into a steep curve and slides towards the Tyrell Corporation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every government that could was racing to populate their colonial territory.  But emigrants needed incentive.  Over-population and the greenhouse factor didn't seem to be enough; but owning a human look-a-like had lots of appeal. It was big industry, the competition was stiff and Tyrell was top of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spinner gently touches down.  The hatch drops open and Deckard steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His claim to fame was making a product more human than human and sometimes the 'more' turned out to be a problem.  This wasn't just an escaped andy who broke his owner's arm -- there were twenty-eight people dead and the pressure was on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard walks up to a desk, hands his I.D. to a guard who checks it against a list on a screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But so far they'd always managed to keep it quiet.  Not to say that once in a while there wasn't bad publicity.  Some fanatic bitching about equal rights for andies or an occasional trade union proclaiming it was aun-American for automatons to take jobs away from humans on the colony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard hands Deckard back his I.D., pushed a button and Deckard walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what's more American than good old supply and demand?  The Government needed them, industry made them and the church backed them.  The big religious boys said that Androids, no matter how human, were objects; only God could make people. I'm not religious, but I was inclined to agree. Otherwise I'd be out of a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator door slides open.  The young lady inside would look right standing on a cliff, hair blowing in the wind, looking out to sea in a 19th Century painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Deckard.  My name is Rachael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard tips his head to her and steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No woman can be all things to all men, the Rachael comes closer than most.  The only trouble is she's all busi- ness.  Formidable without really trying.  Some beauty is better avoided and Deckard looks straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slides open and they continue down the corri- dor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems your department doesn't believe out new unit is to the public benefit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A humanoid robot is like any other machine, it can be a benefit or a hazard.  If it's a benefit, it's not our problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But because your department can't do an adequate job in detecting the miniscule number at large, it's a problem.  Correct, Mr. Deckard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass into a canopied, air-filtered corridor. Deckard doesn't answer the question because he's looking at the animals.  Small northern animals in neat "en- vironmental" cages.  He looks at the rabbit, the raccoon and the squirrel, but the owl asleep on its perch stops him.  The armed guard at the exit never takes his eyes off them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like our owl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard nods.  Rachael claps her hands.  The owl opens its yellow eyes and blinks at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's artificial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands thrust in her pockets, she strides off towards the exit without looking back. The exit is another tube.  Just big enough for two.  No room for excess.  He tries to ignore her cool appraising stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in a very unique position, Mr. Deckard.  You could affect the future of this entire organization according to how you work your little test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard has nothing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you apprehensive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the responsibility of your power.  Being a police bureaucrat, you've got more than your share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slides open.  Deckard looks down at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it wrong, girl.  I work with the bureau not for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets it sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My job isn't to detect malfunctioning andies, it's to eliminate them.  The more the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out of the elevator first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office is dimly lit, but highlights of resilience reside in the luster of the antique furnishings, like glimmers of gold in a darkened mine.  Dr. Tyrell is a fragile man of power, with that look of "youth" obtained from steroids and surgery.  Dapper and trim, he leans against the desk looking at an old fashioned pocket watch.  The only sound is the insidious PERKING of COFFEE BREWING in the background. Tyrell taps a sensor on his desk.  The door in front of Deckard and Rachael slides open.  They enter a vestibule and face another door, this one befitting the decor of the office, Tyrell slips the watch into his pocket as they enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deckard.  Dr. Eldon Tyrell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Mr. Deckard.  Please sit down.  Would you care for a cup of coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrell pours from an old time sylex into small china cups and hands one to Deckard.  The congenial light in his eyes could almost pass for warmth -- dragon warmth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow, I didn't expect that the man who did the dirty work would be the man to do the technical work.  Here you are, Mr. Deckard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Deckard a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this to be an empathy test?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capillary dilation of the so-called blush response?  Plus fluctuation of the pupil, plus involuntary dilation of the iris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask a personal question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever retired a human by mistake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But in your profession that is a risk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing is infallible, but so far the Voight-Kampff scale bas been foolproof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you said, Mr. Deckard, a machine can be a hazard.  The Voight-Kampff scale is a machine, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One that relies on human interpretation.  Where's the subject?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting next to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard stares at Rachael, then back at Tyrell.  Delighte Tyrell takes a cup of coffee. Accepting the challenge, Deckard opens his briefcase and starts fishing out the apparatus.

dialogues.speaker: THE VOIGHT-KAMPFF 3
dialogues.text: Rachael's eye fills the screen, the iris brilliant, shot with light, the pupil contracting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the soft green glow of the dials, the needles in both gauges are at rest.  Dr. Tyrell stands silhouetted behind Deckard, who sits in front of Rachael, a pencil beam trained on her eye.  Wire mesh discs are attached to her cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're given a calfskin wallet for your birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The needles in both gauges swing violently past green to red, then subside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't accept it.  Also, I'd report the person who gave it to me to the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a little boy.  He shows you his butterfly collection, plus the killing jar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again the gauges register, but not so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd take him to the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're watching T.V. and suddenly you notice a wasp crawling on your wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd kill it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both needles go to red.  Deckard makes a note, takes a sip of coffee and continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a magazine you come across a full-page photo of a nude girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this testing whether I'm an android or a lesbian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You show the picture to your husband. He likes it and hangs it on the wall. The girl is lying on a bearskin rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't let him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be enough for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard frowns, then smiles.  His smile looks a little like a grimace or the other way around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You become pregnant by a man who runs off with your best friend, and you decide to get an abortion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd never get an abortion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be murder, Mr. Deckard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be my child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like you speaks from experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He notes the needles.  One goes green and the other remains inert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last question.  You're watching an old movie.  It shows a banquet in progress, the guests are enjoying raw oysters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both needles swing swiftly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entree consists of boiled dog stuffed with rice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Needles move less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The raw oysters are less acceptable to you than a dish of boiled dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard moves the adhesive discs from her cheeks and switches off his beam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she is, the machine works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The machine works.  She is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachael sits very still.  Except her eyes -- they go to Tyrell and hang on.  He stares back at her as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many questions did it take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachael sits rigidly in her chair, as the ground crumbles around her, her big mermaid eyes locked with Tyrell. His voice is quiet and strong, mesmerizing.  She's hang- ing by a thread. Deckard watches with a bas taste in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Memory implant.  She was programmed. But I think she has transcended her conditioning.  I think she was beginning to suspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachael nods fixedly.  Careful not to let go her grasp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many questions does it usually take, Mr. Deckard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five, maybe six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, carefully, Tyrell unlocks his gaze from Rachael and turns towards Deckard, who is starting to put away his equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to have to be on your toes, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard glances back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a complex problem and we wouldn't want anything to happen to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Less of a man might shrink at the end of Deckard's look, but not Tyrell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the good of all, I recommend you take Rachael with you. Considering her uniqueness, I'm sure she could prove quite helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard almost smiles at the nasty power of Tyrell's style.  He turns away and starts packing up the Voight- Kampff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard is ready to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how is it one man will be able to cover so much ground?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Discreetly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All pertinent information is being fed into your departmental computer, an Esper 231 -- I believe -- and a photo over-lay packet is being produced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deckard, I think it would be wise to reconsider my offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachael sits there very pale and expressionless, her feet flat on the floor, alone is the word. Trying to keep the fury out of it, Deckard's voice comes out in a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the last word, Rachael glances up at him and Deckard turns away. The outer door slides open and he goes through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As seen through the windshield from the passenger side of a vintage Dusenberg.  The headlights cut through the dark, illuminating a narrow strip of mountain road.  A downgrade. A sign slides by stating:  "Caution Curves Ahead." Good advice considering the sheer nightmare of a drop to the right and the wall of solid rock to the left. The steady HUM of the ENGINE and the HISS of the TIRES will remain, but the location suddenly changes to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasant place of soft light and domestic charm.  The young lady in the short dress is vacuuming the rug. Her back to the viewer.  As she bends over to vacuum beneath the couch, exposing her beautiful ass, an admonishment from a resonant and slightly tired MALE VOICE intercedes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's keep our eyes on the road, Deckard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abruptly the VIEW FLASHES BACK TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon is up there slicing through the trees, strobing over the hood of the car.  The road is getting steeper and the corners sharper.  Rags of mist skim by as the Dusenberg picks up speed.  It is becoming a riveting ride, but the passenger's mind moves elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swift, soft clouds overhead.  In the cold shine of the icy light,the viewer walks down an aisle of maples and beeches, their clean hard limbs deflecting the frosty light, and underfoot the crisp, blue-white snow, melted through in spots, exposing soggy patches of rich brown earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, stay with the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dusenberg is going faster now, headlights eating up the road.  Rushing the corners in gut wrenching four- wheel drifts.  Not a pleasant sensation if you don't like roller-coasters. The Dusenberg slides out of a corner and faces a couple hundred yards of straightway leading to the next bend. Good place for a breather, but the driver shifts into high and screws on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold and gray.  The current running strong.  The nose of a kayak points through the swells, the viewer paddling for the shore. This is cold remote country, wild and untouched.  A sky bluer than the Madonna's cloak.  The kayak banks and the viewer steps out, moving over the sandy beach towards a little camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to have to start the sequence again if you don't stay with me, Deckard.  Concentrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know I'm not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not responding to the stimulus.  I can see right here, I'm not getting a reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the Dusenberg the driver turns to look at the passen- ger, his specter-like face obscured by shadow, but by the glint of teeth, he must have just smiled.  And the passenger's view snaps back to the road. Suddenly another pair of headlights round the approach- ing bend.  Large ones, of a bus or a truck.  Blinding. The Dusenberg is going too fast to stop.  No room to pass.  HORNS BLAST.  The Dusenberg brakes, goes into a broadside skid.  The hands of the passenger reach out and grip the mahogany dash.  Brakes locked, TIRES SCREAMING, skidding.  The Dusenberg tears through the railing and plunges into space.  The last view of the passenger is pure vertigo.  Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The good doctor is bending over his glass-top desk which resembles a pin-ball machine.  Displayed under its surface is a network of crisp electronic symbols and read-outs indicating the results of the test. Deckard detached the patches from his forehead, which it a little damp, but other than that, he looks no worse for wear, stands up to stretch and walks over to the doctor's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how did I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Wheeler is a thin boney man, aloof but a promise of compassion in his sunken eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nerves of steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No rust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that.  Your motivity rate checked out a little slower than last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning you don't run as fast as you used to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard starts to dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the road test...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mind kept wandering.  That bothered me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Considering the nature of your work, that could be unhealthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler studies his "desk" for a moment and his finger comes down on the section illuminating Deckard's simple statistics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a birthday coming up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard bends over slipping on his shoes.  Wheeler looks up, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you haven't put in for emigration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to be over the limit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I could make you a long list of complaints about this fucken city but I still rather be here than up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if you change your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll change the limit before I change my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never been more sure of anything in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard is ready to go.  Looking at Wheeler, a little touched with his concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you could?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheeler considers it a moment, smiles and shakes his head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My job is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands and Deckard walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The referee is bouncing around the ring, trying to keep up with the two Mexican light-weights pounding the shit out of each other.  If not for the fuzz and the silence, the audio on the holoscope is off, you might think you were ringside at the Garden.  It's a good fight but Pris isn't watching. She's got her feet up on the couch painting her toe nails.  The room is so quiet you can almost hear the polish.  She starts on her fourth toe when a NOISE form above STOPS HER It sounded like a CREAKING of a FLOOR, but so quiet, sudden and over so fast it's hard to be sure.  She stares at the ceiling a moment, then glances at Sebastian. On the other side of the room, in his own world, Sebastian is peering into his magnifier, soldering gossamer strands with a laser. Pris has crossed the floor and is closing the door quietly behind her.  If the animoids nestled around the ledges of the room are capable of noticing, they'd be the only ones in the room who did.

dialogues.speaker: NOON
dialogues.text: Pris moving smoothly past the doors, some of them open and warped offering sights and shadow and decay.

dialogues.speaker: NOON
dialogues.text: The gloom in here is like the light of the empty well. Her feet against the metal steps reverberate in the hollow silence.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: She's running now, down the hall, stops at the apart- ment directly above Sebastian's and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Mary turns her head as Pris comes in.  She's sitting in a chair.  The only piece of furniture in the room. It's broken and tilts at a funny angle.  She nods and Pris nods back. Batty is lying on his back, rolling his head slightly from side to side like he's soothing a stiff neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not ready yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, he says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty nods he can't wait.  Pris glances at Mary and gives a frigid little smile.  Pris backs out and closes the door behind her.  Batty blows air through his nostrils.  Like an animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is streaked with remnants of a lingering dusk. Prisms of light flash over the sheen of Deckard's car as he cuts off the freeway and sweeps down the off- ramp curve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving through the dark city streets.  Deckard turns a corner and guns it up a long, steep hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the top of the hill the car pulls into a drive and disappears into the subterranean garage of a high-rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's coming down the hall carrying a foil wrapped plastic plate and stops in front of his door.  It's riddled with locks.  He slips a small device out of his pocket, aims it at the door and the locks unlock, the bolts slide open.  He walks in and kicks the door shut behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips on the light and crosses the front room. Deckard is a pack rat -- hard to tell if he just moved in or is just moving out. As he enters the kitchen, the SOUND of SOMEBODY BEHIND him causes him to whirl around fast, hand snapped out in front of him, gun already in it.  Rachael almost got shot.  But she's unruffled, a little pale maybe, but direct as ever.  There's a long, chilly moment, then she almost smiles as her eyes move to the plate on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that your dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard looks down at the over-turned plate and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I called and found out you were on your way home.  These were already delivered to your department but I thought you should have copies as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's holding out a cassette the size of a cigarette pack.  But it's taking Deckard's adrenalin time to recede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Nexus information you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the cassette, but a man with so many locks must be wondering how they were gotten through so easily. He doesn't even want to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He realizes he's still got the gun aimed at her and sticks it back in his belt and they're left staring at each other.  The situation makes awkward silence. At least for him.  She's looking at him like she's got something to say but isn't saying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you think it complicates your work, but I'm here to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already got more help than I need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you need more help than you've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't, but she's not backing off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's two reasons a man rejects help.  Either because he's so good at what he does he doesn't think he needs it, or he's so insecure he can't admit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like I'm an ass-hole either way, but the answer is still no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of us might be more effective than one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lets it sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You use your equipment, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I'm a piece of equipment. Use me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a strong look that passes between them -- a long one.  Maybe if he were on firmer ground he might do something about such an offer but... Deckard's eyes follow her down as Rachael bends to the floor and starts picking the food off the rug, put- ting it back on the plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, I'll get it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends down to help, but she's already done it. Their heads a few inches apart.  Something in her eyes diminishes the distance even more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I make you nervous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she is.  And suddenly he is too.  She hands him the plate and they stand.  She's looking at the floor, almost shy, then she looks up and he's watching her. She says it plain and simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's strange to suddenly realize that what you thought was your life is actually someone else's fabrication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard nods.  He feels it, but doesn't know what to do about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you?  I couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are not some of Deckard's finer moments.  But she doesn't seem to notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A part of me is glad.  I think I feel more.  I don't like who I was before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard nods, waits the respectable interval and is glad to have a plate to take into the kitchen. In the scrambled sanctuary of his kitchen Deckard looks around for a place to put the plate, but things have piled up on him in here.  He contemplates the refrig- erator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why do you think they were after their records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a lot more comfortable talking shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They probably want to find out when they were made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dumps his dinner in the garbage and comes back out. She's writing something on a card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess the date of your birth is important if you know you're not made to last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way he can keep his foot out of it.  She looks up and hands him the card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my number.  If you need me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to the door, opens it but hesitates before going through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better get better locks -- if you want to keep me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks back at him and smiles -- the smile says she's talking about all kinds of locks.  Deckard looks like he might ask her to stay, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down at the number.  It's the back side of a snapshot.   He turns it over.  The picture of a man and a woman.  The little girl between them looks like a six-year old Rachael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sitting in front of his console studying pictures of Nexus Sixes at they appear, blank-faced, hairless and unadorned on his monitor. The over-lay machine is transforming each image with instant attributes; hair, moustaches, teeth, eye colors, age, youth, hats, glasses, etc.  All in rapid succession, running the gambit from ominous to beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The possibilities were infinite. They could change their appearances but not their future. Like she said, it was short. Longevity is what they were after. The garbage man even wanted a past. Poor fuck.  I'd check it out but I knew she was right.  The market worked on turn-over.  Built-in obsolescence was the name of the game.  That meant her too.  It was something I didn't want to think about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On top of the monitor there's an open can of beans with a spoon stuck in it.  Deckard puts out his cigarette and reaches for them as the PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryant here.  Regarding the rundown you requested on job applicants, Esper's concluded that the only irregular category that Tyrell's got is the entertainment section.  You better get on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just about to have my dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you hurry you'll get back before it gets cold.  I got a spinner on your roof in five minutes.  Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard hangs up and looks at the beans.  He didn't want them anyway.  He gets up and walks to the bedroom. Looks through the pile of clothes on the floor, finds his ankle laser and straps it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spinner skirts through the canyons of the city. Deckard, sitting in the contoured seat, watches the maze of suspension bridges, platforms and catwalks swing by below.  The tops of larger buildings shimmer with advertisements and weather announcements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard is cruising low and slow over the city listen- ing to Esper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nexus designated Rachael is a prototype.  Created for in-house use by special mandate form the Scientific Development Regulatory Committee.  Will live conventional term -- no para-physical abilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is a conventional term?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four years.  Which would make her termination date...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind.  Do they have that knowledge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longevity is classified.  No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, gimme a run-down on the three females.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nexus designated Mary:  incept November 1 2017, domestic conditioning non competitive, trained for day care position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nexus designated Pris:  incept data December 13 2017, competitive, programmed to provide pleasure for long term spacers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nexus designated Zhora:  incept June 13th 2017, athletic conditioning, highly competitive, special abilities in the entertainment field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard taking it down.  About to pull it in an already crowded lot, but the sign flashes "FULL."  Deckard doesn't believe in signs; is about to set it down any- way when a Chicano in a fluorescent coat runs out and waves him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pissed, Deckard veers away and buzzes low over and around the roof tops, all dark and cramped -- not a lot of room around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally brings it down between two buildings hardly enough clearance, but he jockeys the machine into an alley, touches down and runs it slowly along the surface -- parking it by a sign that says "NO PARKING."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not many people.  Wind blowing.  A nest of garish small-time clubs. Deckard emerges from one, goes into the next.  The pulsing neon over the entry says "TAFFEY'S BAR."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowded in here.  BONGO MUSIC.  Deckard is at the bar sitting next to a big-bellied man in a black beard who's looking through a viewer.  On the small stage in the background AMAZING RAMA is eating razor blades, a part of her juggling routine. Deckard leaves the bar and walks down a hall towards a door at the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taffey's what's referred to in the trade as a "Chicken Hawk" collector of young girls. It must be so, there's one in the bed.  Thin, pale, about thirteen years old, eyes rolled up under her fluttering eyelids, wires attached to her forehead, lying flat on her back in Taffey's crowded little room. Taffey's a little fella with wide hips and narrow shoulders, wears a jet black toupe and has a face like a seal.  But at the moment he's not present. There's a KNOCK at the DOOR, then the SOUND of a TOILET FLUSHING.  Taffey comes out of the bathroom, heart pounding under his polyester bathrobe, and approaches the door like the guilty fucker he is.  He looks through the peeper. Deckard is out there holding up his I.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taffey Lewis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause lasting the time it takes Taffey not to think of a way to say no.  The door opens and Deckard enters.  Except for the drool coming out of the corner of her mouth, and the fluttering eye-lids, Venus doesn't move a muscle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse my niece there... She's studying for an exam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard takes the  Identikit hard copies our of his pocket and pushing some junk out of the way, fans them out on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like  you to take a look at these pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taffey bends down really close, peering at the pictures from about two inches away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see I lost my contacts a couple of days ago around here somewhere and my sight is a little... What am I supposed to be looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you recognize any of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops at Zhora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one looks familiar, but I don't know.  Naw.  There's one came in today looks a little like this one but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl that doesn't look like that girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  She wanted to know about suck night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know if I wanted to handle her -- I already got a snake act.  But my partner goes down there to the Opera House on suck night to book the good ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's suck night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we call in the trade, audition free-for- alls and most of it sucks. Bit I don't think that's her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talking about the Opera House on the Main?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taffey nods.  Deckard goes to the door and turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book the good ones for where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of places.  The tours, the clubs, the Silicone shows, private parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silicone Valley.  Lots of these science guys never leave that place.  We book two shows a month in there. Those big time techs and bio- guys might be real high zoners up here, but when it comes to the arts, they like it loud and lewd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's starting to get a little gooey.  Deckard tips his head good night and backs out of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onstage four Mexican acrobats, in matching metallic jumpsuits roll head over heels in their rendition of a human wheel.  From the P.A. system the Announcer's voice blares through the cavernous theatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hear it for the Hermano Brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scattered APPLAUSE.  Hand in hand, the Hermano Brothers bow deeply, spring up and trot offstage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next we're gonna see a little charmer who keeps her dancing partner in a basket!  She comes to us all the way from exotic Casablanca.  'Salome.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old boys in the pit strike up a tinny version of "In a Persian Market" as SALOME dances onstage. She's a black-haired beauty in a scant belly dancer costume, a couple of pounds overweight but all in the right places.  She kneels ceremoniously center stage and sets the basket down before her.  Carefully removing the lid, she reaches in and lifts out a four- foot harlequin-patterned python.  Grinding her hips to the music, she rises, holding the coiling snake out like an offering.  Sounds of approval from the audience. The gold coins covering her breasts jingle and shimmer, as she weaves sensuously around the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To scattered APPLAUSE, HOOTS and WHISTLES, Salome flounces offstage, the snake hung around her shoul- ders, looking limp, and makes her way through the narrow corridor to her dressing room.  She's about to enter when:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Miss Salome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns.  Deckard's posture and attitude suggest hum- ble, sleazy persistence.  He comes closer with his shit-eating grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to have a word with you if I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salome stands almost six feet high in her high heels -- she looks down on him with the haughty suspicion of a chick who knows how to handle cheap hits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm with the American Federation of Variety Artists...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up a hand as if to stop her from protesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'm not here to make you join -- that's not my department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances around like a guy who's not supposed to be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an investigator for the Confidential Committee on Moral Abuses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, taking it a little more seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's been reports of management sexually abusing the artists in this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know nothing about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't felt yourself to be exploited by the management in any way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's definitely puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you mean 'exploited'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like to get this position.  Did you or were you asked to do anything lewd or unsavory or otherwise repulsive to your person?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you for real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. You'd be surprised what goes on around here.  I'd like to check the dressing room if I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy might be an asshole but he's funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shrugs and they go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
