dialogues.text: Musty and cramped.  A portable shower, a dressing table and not much else.  Salome takes the snake from around her shoulders and lays it on the dressing table.  Deck- ard watches it undulate into the warmth of the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It that mother real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he's not real.  You think I'd be working here if I could afford a real snake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the snake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard nods.  There's not much costume to take off but she's doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand reaches out to touch it.  As his fingers make contact there's an electric "snap."  He jerks his hand back from the shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeezus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Do your job but don't wreck mine, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slides behind the screen and turns on the shower. Deckard starts creeping around pacing around the room like he's inspecting the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have their ways of doing their dirty work without the victim knowing what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are moving over everything she's got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised what a guy'll go through to get a glimpse of a beautiful body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little dirty holes the bastards drill in the wall so they can watch a lady undress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to his amazement he actually spots one.  It's down low on the wall.  Not a good idea to turn his back on work but he can't resist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what if somebody did try to 'exploit' me?  Who do I go to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the hole Deckard is looking at a pair of fat legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who do I go to about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks back.  She's some out of the shower dripping nude.  She's taken off her black wig.  Her hair is short and blonde. Deckard recognizes her immediately from the identikit. He stares at her a moment too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard grins and she returns it. She takes a towel off the table and starts to dry her body.  The snake noses through the cosmetics, tongue flicking trying to get back to its mistress.  Absently, she reaches out to stroke the snake and suddenly laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever get the feeling things aren't the way they seem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hand closes around the snake's head.  Deckard sees it coming but can't move fast enough.  She strikes him so hard it knocks him off his feet.  Before he hits the floor, she kicks him in the stomach.  The snake whistles through the air again as Deckard rolls out of the way. It slams down so hard it ruptures against the floor. He goes for his laser, but she's already out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard bounds out of the room and sees her go through a door at the other end of the hall.  He sprints after her, arrives at the door and flings it open.  Black- ness.  The SOUND of her high heels CLATTER down the metal steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining heavily. The front of the Opera House is open only to foot traf- fic these days.  A bizarre place on a Friday night, hawkers and whores, the rabble, the poor and the cur- ious mill around the randy-built platforms and brightly lit stands.   Zhora, in just a raincoat, is not out of place in this flea market atmosphere.  Trying not to run, she slices through the mob as quickly as she can. Deckard is not far behind, dodging and side-stepping, trying to move against the tide of people scurrying for shelter. She comes to an intersection and turns out of the mall onto a less crowded street.  She glances over her shoulder as she breaks into a run and runs right into a couple of pedestrians.  All three go down. Deckard comes out of the crowd in time to spot her get- ting to her feet.  She sees him and runs.  The two ped- estrians are in his line of fire.  He runs past them and drops to one knee, leveling his laser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop or you're dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't.  The beam flashes through the air, but she's already around the corner. With his bottom lip between his teeth, it hurts to move so fast, Deckard jack-legs it into the street and jumps in front of the first car coming.  It screeches to a stop.  Deckard scrambles for the door, but the guy be- hind the wheel has other ideas.  He peels out fast. The next car slows down and swerves trying not to hit him.  Deckard goes for the door and before the old ma- tron inside can lock it, Deckard's yanked it open and jumps in.  She screams as he pushes her into the pas- senger seat and jams the car into a wrenching about face.  The lady squeals like a pig as the momentum plasters her against the door. Deckard slams it around the corner and guns it down the street.  It's long and it's empty and it's going by fast. Nothing the old lady cares to see -- she's got her hands over her eyes, whimpering, hoping she'll faint before she dies. Deckard takes the next left so hard he almost lays it over.  As the car bounces off the curb he floors it. Zhora's a hundred yards ahead, halfway down the street, trying to make it back into the crowded mall.  She's running fast, but the car is faster. As he passes her, Deckard hits the brakes and skids broadside seventy feet.  The door flies open and he rolls out FIRING. Zhora's ducking it with no where to go, except... The showcase window on her left EXPLODES as she crashes through. It's a corner shop joined to a series of stores, front- ing the mall.  Deckard runs to the opening she's made and pours FIRE through the tunnel of her jagged wake as Zhora breaks through one window after another, getting sliced, getting shot, trying to get away from Deckard's laser.  But she doesn't. His last shot burns a hole through the base of her skull.  It kills her but doesn't stop her.  Her speed takes what's left of her through the last two windows and into the street where she runs into a parked car with such force that she embeds herself in the side of it. Hunched over, breathing hard, Deckard comes slowly for- ward.  The crowd starting to gather.  There's something for everybody and they're coming from all directions. Deckard moves through them, edging to have a look. It's not a good thing to see.  It looks like Salome and the car tries to eat each other.  A bloody feast of metal and flesh. Deckard bows his head, sick, exhausted.  So much commo- tion he doesn't notice THREE COPS closing in from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard has his back to them.  They're fanned out and crouched, ready to fire.  Deckard drops his laser.  Two of them rush up, spin him around while the third does a frisk. TWO MORE COPS arrive, wary and wild-eyed, pushing the people back -- his is not a good place for cops. Deckard's ankle laser is discovered by the Cop frisking him.  With a snarl he pulls it out and hands it back to the SERGEANT covering the action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your belly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard's not in the mood for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Sergeant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's reaching for his ID.  The Cop with the rubber billy hits him in the head. One thrill after another.  Somebody in the crowd YEOWLS. The last thing Deckard hears as he falls.  The Cop reaches inside Deckard's coat for the concealed weapon they missed, but it's an ID card.  He looks at it for a moment, then looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Sarge, this guy's a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An embarrassing situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear this fuckin' crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cops start pushing.  And for one split second one of the crowd looks a lot like Leon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your standard low class crapper.  Bryant is planted firmly on the cracked tile floor next to the urinals rubbing his face, trying not to pop the clutch in his anger.  This is a public place, he doesn't want to yell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because it's a Nexus 6 doesn't change procedure.  A little known fact can become a well-known fact and part of our job, Deckard, is to make sure that doesn't happen. Now how can be do that if you blow one away in front of a fuckin' audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the sort of question that expects an answer. Deckard's washing his face in the basin hoping it'll all go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard looks up dripping, reaches for a paper towel. Bryant slaps one in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was gonna get away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let her get away.  I thought you were a pro -- you're supposed to be a fuckin' tracker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryant takes a couple of deep breaths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say you got a little carried away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard's voice is barely audible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't like her!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the handle on one of the urinals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You start liking or disliking andies it's time to hang it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PLUMPING ROARS and SUCKS and DIES.  There's nothing to do but nod.  Deckard nods.  Poor bastard has had a rough night.  Bryant pulls a flask out of his coat and hands it to him.  Deckard puts it to his mouth and Bryant watches Deckard's Adam's apple like he's count- ing the swallows.  Deckard hands it back empty.  Bryant caps it, puts it back in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, go home.  Get some rest. Take an aspirin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bryant shuffles out like an old bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheap whiskey and bad wine.  That's the kind of place this is.  It's near closing.  But still a few at the bar.  Alcoholic silhouettes. In the b.g. Deckard comes down the passage from the men's room and stops at the phone.  He gets a number out of his pocket and calls it.  As he talks he leans against the wall, his body language intimate and chummy. Not much action at the bar other than somebody snoring and a dipso down at the end having a conversation with himself. Deckard hangs up, walks to the bar and straggles a stool.  The BARTENDER's a big lady with tits like sand bags and a voice that plays no favorites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't protect your drinks, mister; while you was in the potty, this hummer snatched it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard glances at his stool-mate.  A huge MAN, slumped over the bar like a beached whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.  Gimme another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whale doesn't move, but it speaks, with a gravelly Russian accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me.  I thought was free drink.  I will pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the big man's digging through his pockets.  Deck- ard's drink arrives and the Russian raises his head. It's a big melancholy face with a glint of warmth in his red-rimmed eyes and a smile that could melt your heart.  But it's Leon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I have no money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.  Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I would like to buy you drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll but you one.  What'll you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vodka!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot of vodka, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard brings out his smokes.  Offers one.  Leon takes it and they light up.  The drinks come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prosit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prosit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the hatch.  Leon slaps his glass on the bar, reach- es into his pocket, brings out a little match box and slaps that down too.  It's done with such pride that Deckard has to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to see my friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, don't have the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon smiles broadly and with ceremonious care opens the box and dumps three live cockroaches on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those cockroaches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard looks interested.  One of them starts to scamp- er away, but Leon walls off the next with his huge hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you had these guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two months.  But this one is not guy.  It is girl.  His girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon leans closer like he doesn't want the cockroaches to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Usually Blackie waits until Igor is eating; then, when his back is turned, he tries to take advantage of Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard nods, definitely interested.  He signals the bartender for another round.  The drinks arrive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prosit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prosit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the hatch.  Their eyes meet at the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never saw a cockroach make love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard shakes his head, but he'd like to. Leon smiles slyly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon brings a cube of sugar out of his pocket and puts it on the bar.  They both lean down and watch intently. The drinks come and are put away, but the cockroaches are not cooperating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be that he is not hungry or maybe she is not hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon is catching the roaches and one by one puts them back in their box.  He holds up the last and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like to kiss her goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure you take your girlfriends with you when you leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What neither of them notices is that between Leon's fingers, his stub of his cigarette is burning his flesh. Deckard lifts his glass, it is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta piss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard gets on his feet, leans forward like a man in a stiff wind and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll piss outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon watches his walk a perfect straight line through the bar down the passage and out of the rear exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard reels out.  The door swings shut and he's sober as hell and moving fast.  Around the big trash dumpster alongside the building, he plasters himself against the wall and his gun is out, aimed at the door.  He's in a good spot with a perfect line of fire.  Moments go by and he's glad for the time to steady himself.  The SOUND of his BREATHING, the HUM of the city and the quiet. Suddenly from behind, Deckard is swept off his feet and twirled around in Leon's bear-trap embrace. Leon lets go and Deckard hits the pavement, skidding hard enough to tear clothes and burn skin, but he rolls out of it and comes up with gun in hand; but Leon is so fast he's already there and kicks it out of his hand. Leon moves towards him, backing Deckard against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you know where Zhora was so quick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand is lightning.  It shoots out, grabs Deckard's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I showed pictures.  Somebody recognized her.  I went to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard is pale.  The sweat is starting to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grip tightens and twists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My birthday is April 10, 2015. How long do I live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard's knees come up fast.  Leon's fist comes down faster, like a hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Painful to live in fear, isn't it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard is doubled over, hugging his thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's how it is to be a slave.  The future is sealed off, he grovels, he waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even hurt, Deckard is fast.  He goes for his ankle gun, but Leon's got it out of his hand before he can even raise it and throws it down the alley. Deckard hurls forward, knocking him off balance, and scrambles to get away.  Leon grabs him by the foot, drags him back and jerks him off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sex, reproduction, security, the simple things.  But no way to satisfy them.  To be homesick with no place to go.  Potential with no way to use it.  Lots of little oversights in the Nexus 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams Deckard into the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, nothing is worse than having an itch you can never scratch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard slides down the wall to his knees and huddles, protecting his head with his arms, waiting for the next one. Leon folds his big hands together and raises them over his head, pausing just a second to savor the satisfac- tion of smashing Deckard's skull. The spasm that runs through Leon's face is not from satisfaction.  It's the bullet that went through his neck.  He hits the ground hard, his big teeth biting the air like a rabid dog.  Dead. Rachael is standing in the alley.  Deckard lies there looking at her.  She comes slowly and quietly forward and drops Deckard's gun by his side. Deckard gets to his hands and knees and tries to get up, but can't quite manage it.  He looks up at her, panting, spits blood and almost smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said, I don't need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a long moment, she bends down to touch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look terrible, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lying in the tub with a drink, eyes half mast, water up to his chin, bruised and beat, but looking just a little wicked in his balmy luxury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew a cop once who was involved in a high-speed chase.  They shot out one of his tires and he went over a cliff at hundred and fifty miles an hour.  They found him in the morning with a broken skull, six fractured ribs and second- degree burns.  On the way to the hospital he made a play for the nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a drink and clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  I thought you were supposed to be taking care of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't answer.  Lies there sipping his drink. Rachael comes in a little uncertain, a little droll, and stands there looking down at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't just stand there looking at me.  It's not polite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits on the edge of the tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme your arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's wearing a short-sleeved dress.  It's a long, del- icate arm and Deckard holds it, inspecting it like a maestro with a Stradivarius.  He looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever take a bath with a man before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot I haven't done with a man before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got her hand in the water and had begun to soap her arm.  Starting with her wrist and running the bar to her elbow, up and down, slow and slippery.  She watches, not quite sure of the ritual. He pulls her closer, and runs his hand up higher, mould- ing and pressing, working around her flesh, up and under her arm into the privacy of her dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting me wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.  For a moment Deckard stares at her like some furry-legged satyr in rut, the fingers of his other hand rake through her hair and into the water she comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bed looks like it was hit by a storm and Deckard looks like something that was washed up in it.  He's spread out flat, face creased and puffed. His eyes squint open, but only for a moment.  His hands are more reliable.  They search over the bed, but find it bare.  He edges his head over the side, looking around for signs, but she's all gone.  He gets up in two stages, sits and then stands.  Then sits again, resting his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard's got his face in the mirror shaving it.  It's been a long night.  Nothing a new tongue and a trans- fusion wouldn't put right.  He moves a couple of inches to the left so his eyes have a view of the tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard is on the edge of the couch with the phone on his knees, the card with Rachael's number in his lap and having no luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I am not in at the moment, but if you'll leave your name and number I'll return your call as soon as I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not soon enough.  Deckard hangs up, puts the phone on the floor and leans back on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rooster perched on the chair spreading its scrawny wings, strains from the tips of its toes, crowing at the ceiling.  Between crows there's a TAPPING at the door. You might call this a "barnyard" apartment.  There's straw on the floor and several hens roosting against the back wall.  The front door opens a few inches and Sebastian pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deetchum?  Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody seems to be home except his chickens.  As Sebas- tian enters, closing the door behind him, a goose charges out of the bedroom hissing and honking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now, Waddles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeming to recognize Sebastian as no intruder, Waddles veers off from the attack.  As Sebastian crosses the room a pig peeks out from behind the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Wrigley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the chickens and collects some eggs, putting them into a bowl he's brought.  He puts down the bowl and reaching into his pocket carefully counts out the payment and puts the money on a plate.  He's about to leave but notices there's no water in the dispenser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Deetchum isn't taking very good care of you people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pouring from a jug on the table, he fills the dispenser with water, scatters a little grain on the floor, gets his bowel of eggs and leaves. Wrigley grunts and comes out from behind the couch for a long drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian arrives on his floor, walks down the hall to his apartment, opens the door, walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to close door, comes face to face with Roy Batty.  Sebastian drops his bowl of eggs.  Batty's hand flashes out and catches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiling, Batty hands them back to Sebastian, who is too startled to speak. Pris runs up and gives Batty and Mary a big hug, steps back effusing and smiling, everybody's favorite teen- ager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my Uncle Roy, Sebastian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, glad to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pumps Sebastian's free hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my Aunt Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian turns and there's Aunt Mary, modest and warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is my savior, J.F. Sebastian, everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian stands there with his eggs, bashful and ex- cited, the hero of this little family's warm attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't thank you enough, Mr. Sebastian. If you hadn't come along...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were worried to death.  It's awfully kind of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian is nodding and smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not used to the big city. Where we come from it's not so easy to get lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You certainly have a nice place here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well stocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty looks around admiringly.  Sebastian mumbles some- thing that sounds like "Thank you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian doesn't like to go out too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep a lot of provisions right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like a man who stays put.  An admirable thing to be able to sustain yourself in these times. You live here all by yourself, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no, not really.  There's Mr. Deetchum, he's the watchman, he lives on the first floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody nods.  A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't found it easy, Mr. Sebastian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They glance around the room, waiting for Sebastian to pick up the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about breakfast, I was just going to make some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it wouldn't be too much of a bother... a little bite to eat would be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no bother, I'd be glad to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, actually

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're famished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian is truly happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, then.  You make yourselves comfortable and I'll bring the food right out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disappears into the kitchen.  Batty looks happy with the way things are going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pris comes up close.  Her tone muted but demanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty finds her attitude amusing, which makes her even more pugnacious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to know what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a punitive edge to Batty's response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only three of us left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pris is shocked.  Her whisper comes out a hiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we're stupid and we'll die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if everybody is doing their job here at home.  How are things at home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little spotted pig on the table sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home again, jiggidy jig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all turn and stare at the pig.  Batty is delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't trust him.  I don't think he knows what he's doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BELL-TONE from the microwave goes off in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows what he's doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he won't cooperate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Sebastian is a host who wants to be appreciated.  We'll appreciate him and he'll cooperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden is laid out in an apparatus that resembles an iron lung.  A little above his head, facing him, is a bank of bio-feedback lights registering body functions. Deckard is in a chair sitting next to his friend. Holden has lost weight, his face is grey, he can't move his head, but he's smiling like the cat who ate the canary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you doing, old man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden's voice is just a whisper -- the kind of whisper that comes out of the joker at the back of the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm great.  I mean, I know I'm not really great, but I feel just great.  How you like my new suit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you don't have to worry about getting it wrinkled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden's eyes close, his smile gets bigger and little spasms of laughter pump out of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make me laugh.  It makes me pee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's okay.  I like to pee. So how are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what I hear you're doing great.  Bryant tells me you're going like a god damn one-man army.  Making a lot of money, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (pause) But that's what I wanted to talk to you about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I got a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm starting to empathize with these Nexus-sixes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden giggles.  Starts to laugh again.  A blue light on the panel begins to turn very bright.  They both notice it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking a piss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wait for the light to abate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something, Deck. You been having intimate relations with one of these units?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard doesn't deny it.  Holden smiles like a cherub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I thought... one of the liabilities of the trade -- you has sex with your prey, old buddy.  That's bound to create problems, unless you're a black widow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard has to wait for him to stop giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about -- not sex -- but love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden bites his bottom lip to keep the laugher out of his voice, but he can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love is just another name for sex. Love is sexy and sex is lovely -- I don't care what you call it, an android can't have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These aren't just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what they are, Deck -- Look, maybe they can pretend to feel, but far as the raw, hot emotions of the old heart -- no way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden stops talking for a moment to get some air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, take it from an old pro, no matter how good we get, we're never gonna make an artificial anything that can feel.  It's a contradiction. You might as well go fuck your washing machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden laughs, Deckard doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go out there and keep up the good work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden's whispers have become harder to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to save it, Deck, I'm getting sleepy.  It's been good talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's already asleep.  Deckard stands there a moment looking at him, then walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sitting on the couch, glum, contemplative. There's a SOUND.  His eyes move to the door.  Those locks are opening again.  Rachael comes in.  Looks surprised to see him.  Him too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I'd come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't hear me.  You were sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He likes that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you glad I'm here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is.  She's spunky.  Hasn't seen this place in the daytime.  Pleased, he watched her move around the mess. She spots a little framed photograph.  Picks it up. It's a man with a shotgun and a boy holding up a quail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and my dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts it down and comes to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you're not on the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.  Part of my job is to sit on a couch and try and figure things out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits next to him. Pleased as hell, they both sit there staring straight ahead.  He looks at her.  She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do people do in the afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they are smart, they take naps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're under the sheet.  Rachael is on her back, look- ing at the ceiling, hair sprawled like sea grass over the pillow.  Deckard lies next to her, a man studying a treasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you dream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand moves over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wishing is a kind of dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand goes under the sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She feels good.  He moves closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you cry when your father died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's another thing I can't do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her lightly on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody is freer than when he dreams.  I read that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't very good last night, was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I have nothing to compare it to.  I guess I thought there was something more to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I think I missed something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.  Is there a secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her face is close.  She's looking right at him.  Her lips are right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  If there is I'd like to find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly their lips touch and his arms slide under her body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty, Pris and Mary sit at the table staring at their host.  Sebastian is staring back, his fork halfway to his mouth, looking from face to face.  Although nothing is being said, he's totally comfortable, as much at home with them as he is with his animoids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you staring at us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just all so... so different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty nods his head, smiling, sending home the fact and Sebastian is certainly getting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, Sebastian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're androids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all so perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian is smiling from ear to ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What generation are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nexus - 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian whistles.  Mary's head is shaking slightly. Pris gets up and moves to the couch.  Batty couldn't be more pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can trust Sebastian, ladies. He's been working with mechanisms all his life.  He's a wizard and a very perceptive man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian looks like a kid on Christmas Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice is trembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a million things, but he's too excited to think of one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not computers, Sebastian, we're physical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pris perks up proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think, therefore I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, Pris.  Now show him why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a command Pris is pleased to obey.  She sits quiet- ly a moment, hands folded in her lap, prim and proper. Mary doesn't like these displays, but Batty is beaming. Those hands in Pris' lap suddenly move, almost faster than the eye can see and slam down on either side of her, digging into the material with such ferocity that Sebastian jumps.  She plunges into the guts of the couch up to her elbows and comes up holding springs and stuff- ing.  Except for the clenched teeth, she is smiling like an angel. Sebastian is riveted, his eyes wide and astounded, like he's just seen the devil.  He laughs nervously, glad that the devil is a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a lot in common.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean that you can't come here and I can't go there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not only that, but we have smiliar problems.  Accelerated decrepitude. But we don't want to die quite yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could help us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know much about biomechanics, Roy.  I wish I did, but you're out of my league.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we don't find help soon, Pris hasn't got long to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian sneaks a glance.  Pris is staring at him with big childlike eyes, Sebastian looks back at Batty, moved but helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your friend, the man who owns this building?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Tyrell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not really my friend.  I just do a job for him now and then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrell could help us, Sebastian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His company made us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be happy to mention it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be better if I could talk to him in person.  But he's not an easy man to get to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do you deliver your project?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty leans forward and looks right into Sebastian's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you help us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no way Sebastian could say no, even if he wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pris sits up smiling.  Mary sighs a breath of relief and Batty leans back nodding in gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure glad you found us, Sebastian.  What do you think, Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think there is another human being in this whole world who would have helped us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pris gets up and comes to Sebastian and kisses him. That has a lot of impact.  Sebastian looks around try- ing to keep the tears from coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're our best and only friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachael is lying across the bed in one of Deckard's shirts, her chin over the edge, her eyes moving around the room.  Deckard lies next to her.  Looking like a man who died a voluptuous death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was the last time you cleaned this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever cleaned your apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be fooled by appearances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It appears to be dirty -- why don't you get somebody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rolls over to admire her legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they would ruin the arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses the back of her thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They could clean around the arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like people snooping around my stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her other thigh, gets up and goes into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a vacuum in the front room closet is you wanna give it a try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachael lies there a moment, then gets up and goes into the front room and opens the closet door.  The vacuum is not easy to get to, but finally she wrestles it out.  As she starts to plug it in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's wrapped in a sheet, watching her from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if I don't plug it in how can I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind the plug, just go through the motions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then how can you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like the noise.  Just practice.  Practice makes perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him like he's nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious.  Go ahead.  Show me how you would do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly she makes some half-hearted passes with the thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about under the couch there. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bends over to get it.  Deckard pulls up a chair and sits down with his chin in his hands.  She looks back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This feels stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for a smart girl to feel stupid.  Part of your education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drops the vacuum and sits on the floor.  Deckard gets up and comes towards her.  Her eyes travel halfway down his sheet and she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sick, Deckard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never felt better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mansion and opulent grounds.  Sebastian's humble truck parked among richer relations, including a spinner and a 1928 Dusenberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The den.  It contains a collection of big game trophies, and among all this sits Sebastian very straight and proper with an "egg" the size of a basketball in his lap. Old Hannibal Chew was right, the rich make you wait. Sebastian stands and carefully makes his way between the trophies to a window with a view of the grounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrell's young WIFE sits on the diving board watching her husband in the pool with their youngest TOT.  And two older LADS swim around trying to outdo each other for their dad's attention. From the sidelines an old servant pauses to watch the fun, then continues with a tray of mugs towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And beyond on a plateau overlooking the grounds, a figure stands watching, waiting like a bird of prey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a gravel path between shrubs of winter roses, Tyrell turns to observe the last quiet light over his kingdom. The moment is sweetened by the LOW PLAINTIVE BELLOW of one of the animals. He strolls by an old gardener who tips his cap, pro- ceeds up the steps and into his mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to a tray of cookies and milk, Sebastian sits pa- tiently with the "egg" in his lap.  As the door opens he gets to his feet expectantly.  It's STYLES, Tyrell's bodyguard.  He could play the Giant in Jack and The Beanstalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll take that now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian would rather put it in the boss's hands, but Styles takes it and is almost through the door when Sebastian stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He almost forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't fly without the pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian hands him a little box.  Styles stuffs it in his pocket and shuts the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motionless and monumental, six buffalo stand like stat- ues in the grass.  Suddenly they swing their shaggy heads to watch something pass. In the dark silence Batty stops to look at the curious beasts and then moves soundlessly towards the mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a medieval-sized hall.  The piece de resistance is an 18th Century, English painting of an Arab stallion, gleaming like coal over the CRACKLING fireplace. The entire family is seated at the table which glitters for the festive occasion.  Presents gathered around the oldest child. Styles hands the "egg" to Tyrell.  A hush falls over the table.  This is Dad's big present.  Tyrell sets is down before the boy. IAN is a fresh, slim lad who is ten today.  He looks up at his father, then, beaming, pries open the "egg's" hinged lid.  Tyrell's hand goes to his pocket and the griffon steps out of the shell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Basically an avian invention, it has wings and plumage, the head of an eagle, the body of a lion and weighs no more than eight pounds.  It cranes its neck and testing its balance, stands on one leg and then hops to the edge of the table and into the air. The littlest tot claps her hands as the griffon beats its wings rapidly and rises towards the ceiling.  Turn- ing in a forty-five degree, it suddenly drops into a dive. Delighted, the children shriek and scream as the griffon swoops over their crouching heads and sails the length of the hall -- its silhouette flickering briefly over the ancestral portraits of the Tyrell clan. Reaching the end of the room, it banks sharply and flies back towards the table, cups its wings, spreads its tail and comes in for an awkward landing.  They're laughing and clapping as it waddles down the table and knocks over a glass and stops in front of Ian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa!  Did you make this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  We can make man, but not a griffon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends down and kisses his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have to give the cottage industry a chance too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased he excuses himself and heads for the den.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrell comes in and sits behind his desk.  Sebastian hands down the invoices.  Tyrell glances over them and writes out a check. He looks up to hand it over when he sees Batty against the wall, by the door.  For a fraction of a second he's shocked, but recovers fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friend of yours, Sebastian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, this is someone who wants to talk to you, Dr. Tyrell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name is Batty.  Roy Batty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very slowly Tyrell's hand moves towards the back side of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To act without understanding could lead to the very thing the act seeks to avoid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in Batty's eyes completes the warning.  Tyrell decides to heed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little talk it all I need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrell looks at Sebastian.  Considers consequences. Back to Batty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to talk in private then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty thinks it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  It might be better if we talk in private, Sebastian.  Why don't you go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your check, my boy.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dr. Tyrell.  I'll see you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips out closing the door behind him.  Opens it again and sticks his head it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone. If Tyrell is scared he's doing a good job of concealing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised you didn't come to me sooner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not an easy thing to meet your maker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what can he do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can the maker repair what he makes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to be modified?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had in mind something a little more radical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that's a little out of my...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty cuts in with a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want more life, fucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty walks forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The facts of life.  I'll be blunt. To make an alteration in the evolvement of an organic life system, at least by men, makers or not, it fatal.  A coding sequence can't be revised once it's established.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because by the second day of incubation any cells that have undergone reversion mutation give rise to revertant colonies -- like rats leaving a sinking ship.  The ship sinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about E.M.S. recombination?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've already tried it -- ethyl methane sulfonate is an alkylating agent and a potent mutagen -- it creates a virus so lethal the subject was destroyed before we left the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty nods grimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then a repressor protein that blocks the operating cells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't obstruct replication, but it does give rise to an error in replication, so that the newly formed DNA strand carries a mutation and you're got a virus again... but all this is academic -- you are made as good as we could make you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not to last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it this way.  Rolls Royces are made to last -- as least they were. But I'm afraid you're a Ferrari. A high strung racing car -- built to win, not to last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty smiles bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also you're too valuable to experiment with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrell can't help a flash of pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bast of all possible androids. We're proud of our prodigal son -- glad you're returned.  You're quite a prize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoulders hunched, Batty looks down, an uncharacteristic note of guilt in his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done some questionable things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also extraordinary things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing the God of biomechanics wouldn't let you in heaven for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share a laugh.  In spite of himself, there's a look of relief in Tyrell's face as Batty extends his hand. Tyrell takes it and they shake.  The reverence in Bat- ty's eyes caused Tyrell a fatherly smile.  The smile turns into a growl as he feels the bones in his hands crack.  Before the scream comes out of his mouth, Batty stifles it. Tyrell claws at the iron fingers, but they're sinking into his face.  Placing his other hand behind Tyrell's head, Batty squeezes them together and squashes the man's head like a melon.  The mess is not small. Palms up, like a surgeon, Batty walks to the drapes and wipes off the gore and without looking back, strolls out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Styles is coming down the hall.  He sees Batty coming towards him.  Styles looks at him curiously, this is not one of the guests.  As they close, Batty smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you tell me where the bathroom is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Styles doesn't get a chance to answer.  Batty's hand has torn into his crotch.  The man is lifted off the floor, up the wall and held a moment.  Whatever is encased in his pelvis is pulverized.  Batty lets go.  Styles hits the floor.  He died of shock.  Grinding his teeth, Batty continues towards the SOUNDS OF THE FESTIVITIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The birthday cake has arrived, the candles lit.  They're waiting for Dad.  Mrs. Tyrell looks around to find Batty observing from the doorway. A little startled, a little curious, but ever the cor- porate wife, she smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty smiles back and shakes his head in mock regrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the sink the faucet is on.  The water pink with blood.  Batty is washing his hands. A portly maid emerges from the pantry.  Batty looks up. She stops, embarrassed at being caught.  Her eyes no- tice drops of blood on the floor and follow them to the door.  When she looks back, Batty is right in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Books scattered on the bed.  Rachael sitting cross- legged with one in her lap, looking through exquisite shots of nature.  Deckard is next to her, watching her like a lover, like a father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'd never seen the great outdoors. Never even seen books on the subject.  She went through everything I had, and we talked. And there were subjects we didn't discuss and they were words we didn't say, I couldn't say, like death, like future, like real.  But it was hard because she was curious and full of questions.  She was more alive than anyone I'd ever known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up stunned by the beauty of a photo, but with no need to comment.  It's in her eyes.  She stares at him, a revelation taking shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and I are good friends, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He considers it and she stares at him, smiling at the wonder of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Convinced and not convinced, he nods his head.  She laughs at his solemnity.  She's irresistible.  Deckard's pretty irresistible himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever known anybody a long time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a long time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.  Nobody could stand me that long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHIME on the PHONE next to the bed GOES OFF.  He reaches out and brings it to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Bryant.  Are you alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a number.  Canapt 1700, tenth floor, Villa Vita District, Olympia South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, here it is.  Eldon Tyrell, his family and half his staff were just massacred.  The cat is about to get out of the bag.  Pressure is definitely on.  The Nexus program is terminated.  When you finish there, locate Nexus designated Rachael and retire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't, we will.  It has to be total, Deckard.  That's an order from as high as it comes.  Got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the receiver and gets up.  She watches him from the bed.  The gun goes into his belt.  He loads the ankle job and straps it on.  She watches every move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you call it retire, why don't you call it murder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think anything that can suffer deserves to be considered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andies only simulate suffering -- if they're programmed for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I simulated what happened between us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without looking at her, he puts on his jacket. He's standing in the middle of the floor with his back to her.  He turns and they're facing one another. Neither of them moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave here.  Don't open the door, don't answer the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference will it make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That some of the folks around here are more programmed then me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what else I think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was the best day of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and goes through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian is putting his work table in order, but his mind is not with it and his hands are trembling. Batty, Pris and Mary are on the other side of the room talking:  their voices low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go while there is still time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to be trapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You underestimate the trap, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian has almost reached the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going, Sebastian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just thought I'd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you stay here with us.  Out last night together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all watch. Sebastian walks away from the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of yourself as a light, Mary. Shine before you're turned off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's too fragile for that logic, but it appeals to Pris.  She and Batty hold a look that burns. Sebastian is by the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone is coming here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Batty goes to the window and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One man. (he smiles) He must be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then go get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wouldn't be very sporting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian looks ready to bolt.  Batty puts an arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, but don't kill him.  Save a little for everybody.  A masterpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn out the lights, Pris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dim, nocturnal light, Deckard crosses into the courtyard fronting the building and stops.  He looks around.  Nobody there, just silence. He comes closer to the building and stands in the sha- dows off to one side of the entry. His head jerks up to the SOUND OF CRASHING GLASS. Sebastian comes hurtling down and explodes into the pavement thirty feet below. Deckard's eyes move up the line of descent, the shat- tered window on the next-to-top floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much to see, But Deckard misses none of it as he crosses the floor and positions himself in the spot of least exposure.  He looks around.  Elevator and stair- well. Close to the wall, he moves towards the elevator, keep- ing an eye on the stairwell door. Stepping to one side, he hits the button.  The elevator door slides open.  He reaches in, presses a button and as the doors slide shut, Deckard slips a pen between the doors, jamming the operation. Deckard's shoes and soundless as he quickly crosses the lobby floor.  He pauses a moment in front of the stair- well door, then pushes it open and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steps into the dark on the other side.  Suddenly he spins, dropping to the floor, and FIRES three times in- to the figure hovering to his left. The man is hanging off the floor, his arms locked into the railing, neck broken -- with three holes in his chest... but he was already dead. Deckard stares at the corpse.  It's Mr. Deetchum, the old watchman.  That RUSTLING SOUND are rats who were feeding on him, scampering for safer places, Deckard gets to his feet. The stairway rectangles ten stories up.  As his foot touches the first step, a raw, terrified SCREAM shatters the air.  It came from below.  It's the cry of a young girl -- it GROWS TO A PIERCING SHRIEK AND ABRUPTLY STOPS.  Deckard ejects the half-used cartridge from his laser, inserts a fresh one and quiet as the silence, descends the basement stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bottom he faces a corridor.  The FAINT HUM OF MACHINERY comes from the double doors at the far end. The HUM BECOMES A RATTLE by the time he gets there. Each door is fitted with a small window.  Deckard steps to the side and peers through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a gym.  The mirror-lined walls are cracked and tarnished, the equipment atrophied from lack of use. The heavier barbells have sunk into the floor.  Two weight-reducing machines are flapping and grinding away like idiots.  Deckard's eyes stop on the woman. She dangles a few feet off the floor, hung by the shoulders through rings suspended from the ceiling. Her head is slung forward, her body limp and slightly swaying. Deckard pushes open one of the doors until it touches the wall.  Slowly, he advances toward the hanging figure, keeping an eye on the mirror to cover surprises from the door.  He's not breathing hard.  His heart isn't pound- ing.  Deckard's in his element. Close enough to look up into her face, he stops.  It isn't grisly death that causes the reaction in his eyes.  It's the innocence of her angel face. It's not something he has time to consider.  In the mirror behind him, he sees the door starting to open. Deckard spins.  He shouldn't have.  Pris' legs snap up, crack the laser out of his hand and clamp around his neck. Slowly, the door swings closed, but Deckard doesn't notice.  His carotid artery is no longer sending blood to the brain.  He jerks up his foot and reaches down. As his fingers close around the ankle laser, Pris' fingers close around his wrist.  Deckard's hand opens like a flower.  The laser drops to the floor as his eyes roll back into his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naughty, naughty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lets go, but before he can fall, she rams a foot into his back.  He's propelled fifteen feet across the room, slams into a machine and falls to the floor. Pris flies off the rings and comes at him. Deckard reaches out to pull himself up, but she's al- ready there.  Not too hard and just in the right place, she kicks him in the stomach.  He goes back to the floor, gagging for air.  Oh-so-precisely she reaches out with a long index finger and flips the switch on the machine. It's a flab eliminator with a vibrator belt.  Normally an innocuous piece of equipment, but the motor housing on this one is missing.  Lots of GRINDING METAL.  A bad place for flesh and bone. But that's where Deckard's hand is going.  An eight- year-old against a full-down man.  In two more seconds his hand will be ground round.  Deckard tries to pull his hand loose.  It won't come.  He yanks hard, but it's welded in hers. His face is twisted and strained as he raises a leg, wedges his foot against her chest and pushes with all his might.  The hold breaks.  They topple back.  Deckard hits the floor gulping to catch his breath.  Pris is up and coming for him again.  She hovers over him.  Deckard rolls out of the way as she comes down like a pile driver. Reflexively Deckard raises his arm to protect himself. Pris just smiles, takes hold of his foot and drags him across the floor.  She doesn't like to leave a piece of work unfinished.  They're going back to the machine. He goes by a weight-stand of dumbbells and grabs hold. It doesn't stop him.  He's sliding over the floor like it was ice, weight stand in tow. Pris gets to the machine, yanks his foot up and forces it toward the opening.  Deckard sits up, a five-pound dumbbell in his hand, and clobbers her in the back.  It knocks her off balance, but she doesn't let go of his foot.  She hooks out with a fist but misses.  He gets her with a roundhouse in the face. She goes to the floor and Deckard's up, the dumbbell over his head, coming down with it.  Fighting for her life now, Pris drives a foot into his chest.  It lifts him off the floor.  He flies back across the gym and lands in a heap. No more games.  Pris is furious and moving fast.  She rips a steel bar out of the wall and, holding it over- head, charges him like a samurai.  As she comes down for the kill, she freezes. Deckard landed near the laser.  He crawls towards it. As in a nightmare, it takes forever.  But he gets there. He reaches out and grabs the laser, rolls over and takes careful aim.  She charges towards him, screaming her rage.  He FIRES as she comes. The shot amputates her left arm at the shoulder, but her hand doesn't let go of the bar.  It dangles crazily in front of her as she charges forward. He PUTS THE NEXT ONE through her neck.  Pris hiccups a rope of blood as she flies through the air and crashes next to Deckard.  Dead. He lies next to her, chest heaving.  Slowly he rolls over and gets to his hands and knees.  Panting, he stag- gers to his feet and stands over her, swaying slightly. The sound that escapes his throat is raspy and dry.  It might not sound like a war cry, but it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laser in hand, Deckard kicks open the swinging doors and walks into the corridor, a dangerous man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard arrives at the main floor landing, checks his loads and continues up the stairs.  He's going to shoot the next thing that moves and find out later if he was right or wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the next landing he throws the door open.  His eyes move down the hall, looking for prints in the dust. None.  He continues up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the ninth floor he finds what he's looking for. Footprints coming and going from a door halfway down the hall.  He stops to the side of it and listens.  Silence. Deckard FIRES three quick shots through the door.  If somebody were on the other side of it, they aren't now. He kicks the door open and dives through head first and hits the floor in a roll, POURING FIRE into the far corners of the room but the room is empty.  There's a kitchen bar, a closet and a bedroom door, both closed.  Deckard's breathing is the only sound.  No response from either door. Maybe it was a sound, maybe intuition, but suddenly Deckard twists around and FIRES several shots into the closet.  The smouldering door slowly creaks open. Mary is huddled in the rear of the closet.  Her hand out like somebody about to catch a ball but afraid of it.  In her other hand she clutches a button-eyed monkey.  Her face is bewildered, frozen in fear, her body riddled with holes.  No recognition gap here. Deckard SHOOTS her through the neck to make sure.  Mary falls to the floor, like a puppet with her strings cut. Deckard backs away from the pathetic figure in the closet and sits on the sofa, unable to take his eyes off her. Deckard lays the laser down next to him, holds out his hand and looks at it.  It's steady.  He drops it in his lap, closes his eyes and leans back. A TAPPING from the ceiling.  Deckard looks up. A KNOCK -- with the proverbial DOUBLE RAP at the end. A pause.  Deckard jumps out of the way as the ceiling gives in.  Chucks on concrete and plaster hit the couch where he was sitting.  The hole is a couple feet in diameter -- beams cracked through, exposing the apartment above.  Silence.  Deckard wipes the plaster dust from his eyes and mouth, then whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard comes out onto the landing.  Taking his time, he climbs the steps to the next floor, the last floor. He SHOOTS the hinges out of the big stairwell door, pushes it with his foot and it comes down with a BANG. The REVERBERATIONS turn into silence.  The corridor is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving fast but cautious, he passes each door until he gest to the apartment above Sebastian's.  Slowly he turns the know and pushed open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except for the hole in the middle of the floor, there's nothing to see.  Back against the wall, he moves to- wards the bedroom, but stops at the NOISE.  It sounds like the HOOTING OF AN OWL and it's coming from the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard looks around the corner of the door down the hall.  Batty's at the other end.  Except for jockstrap and gym shoes, he's nude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard FIRES.  Batty's fast.  He ducks into a doorway. Pops out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not very sporting to fire on an unarmed opponent.  I thought you were supposed to be good.  Aren't you the man?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The makeup on Batty's face is somewhere between a Coman- che warrior and a transvestite.  The immensity of his insolence awesome -- the muscles of his body are swol- len, trembling from the thrill of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is how we do it up there, lad! Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a blue of lightning-like action, Batty whips down the hall, zigzagging off the walls towards Deckard so fast that Deckard gets only three SHOTS off before the blur crashes through the wall on his left with a laugh. Deckard stands there a moment -- digesting the impact of it, then edges up to the gaping wall.  Batty is be- hind him. He knees Deckard in the back and slaps him in the head. Deckard goes to his knees, then over on his face. Batty kneels next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not hurt, are you?  You better get it up or I'm going to have to kill you.  Unless you're alive you can't play.  And if you don't play, you don't get to be alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard's eyes are closed, mouth bleeding.  He exhales and makes and effort.  He slides his hands up even with his chest and starts to push.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a matador, Batty walks away.  By the time Deckard's on his feet, Batty's disappeared through one of the doors. Deckard wipes the blood from his mouth, bends down and picks up his laser, reloads and looks down the hall, towards the jeering voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Deckard, show me what you got!  I'm right here on the other side of the door.  But you gotta shoot straight 'cause I'm fast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deckard gets to the door, BLASTS it, kicks it open and FIRES at Batty.  But it's only the reflection of Batty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The full length mirror on the other side of the room SHATTERS.  Batty's next to him, grabs Deckard's hand and steps in closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight doesn't seem to be good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're face to face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have a chance, do you?
